data.text:
Heard on the radio yesterday: An old norteÃ±o version of the old, old Hank Thompson hit â€œWild Side of Life.â€ â€œMi Nueva Casa,â€ I learn from musica.com, was a 1982 hit for Los Invasores de Nuevo LeÃ³n, boosting them to their first gold record. That is totally fitting in a number of ways, one being that Texas (Hankâ€™s home state) and Nuevo LeÃ³n are neighbors, and one being that â€œWild Side of Lifeâ€ has a tendency to spin off hits.

Western Swing pioneer Hank Thompson and the Brazos Valley Boys were Billboardâ€™s top country and western band of the year for 14 years straight, 1951-1964. The tune behind â€œWild Sideâ€ itself is â€œan old traditional English melodyâ€ on which the Southern hymn â€œGreat Speckled Birdâ€ was based, according to a biography of Roy Acuff. â€œGSBâ€ was Acuffâ€™s first radio hit and got him a recording contract in 1936. In 1952, â€œWild Side of Lifeâ€ stayed at No. 1 for nine weeks, newly fitted out with lyrics about a temptress who breaks up a manâ€™s marriage and then leaves him to go back to her bar-room good-timing ways â€“ its most famous line being, â€œI didnâ€™t know God made honky tonk angels.â€ That inspired an answer song, â€œIt Wasnâ€™t God Who Made Honky Tonk Angels,â€ the first country No. 1 by a solo female artist, which sold a million copies and launched Kitty Wellsâ€™ career. It put the blame back on men for cheatinâ€™ and was considered so shocking that NBC and the Grand Ole Opry both banned it. Waylon Jennings and Jessi Colter did a mashup of the two songs in 1981, which brings us neatly back around, chronologically speaking, to Los Invasores:

Hank Thompson:

Hank sang (not wrote, but sang):

You wouldnâ€™t read my letter if I wrote you

You asked me not to call you on the phone

But thereâ€™s something Iâ€™m wanting to tell you

So I wrote it in the words of this song

Los Invasoresâ€™ lyrics with my translation (which reads very stilted because Iâ€™m not translating for the feeling of it but literally the words themselves. Language major, sorry ğŸ™‚ I like to know what the original words were and then fill in the feeling):

Te escribi una carta y no me contestaste I wrote you a letter and you didnâ€™t answer me

Fui a buscarte y ya cambiaste direcciÃ³n I went to search for you and youâ€™d already moved (lit., changed address)

Como tengo unas cosas que reclamarte As I have a couple things to complain to you about

me obligaste a que te cante esta canciÃ³n Youâ€™ve obliged me to sing to you this song

The song goes on to talk about how he gave up his home to be with her and is pretty miserable where heâ€™s living now, a place that features bottles, a jukebox and a neon sign. â€œY una cualquiera es la que ocupa tu lugarâ€ â€” and her place is taken by whatever lady is around.

Kittyâ€™s entry in this tuneâ€™s history books:
